## House of Representatives Elections
All 435 House seats will be up for election, along with delegates for D.C. and four U.S. territories (excluding Puerto Rico). At least 11 Democrats hold seats Trump previously won, while 2â€“3 Republicans are in seats won by Harris.

```{r, results='hide'}
#| label: load_spacial_data
us_states <- us_states()
us_congressional_2022 <- as_tibble(st_read(file.path("spacial/congress_albersusa.shp")))
us_congressional_2022 <- us_congressional_2022 |> 
  mutate(id = trimws(id)) |>
  rename(district_id = id)
```

```{r, results='hide'}
#| label: load_house_polling_data

house_polling <- read_csv("polling/house_polls.csv") |>
  select(
    pollster, numeric_grade, pollscore, state, start_date, end_date, 
    sample_size, population, internal, partisan, seat_number, 
    party, answer, candidate_name, pct
  ) |>
  mutate(
    state_abbr = case_when( 
      state == "Alabama" ~ "AL", 
      state == "Alaska" ~ "AK", 
      state == "Arizona" ~ "AZ", 
      state == "Arkansas" ~ "AR", 
      state == "California" ~ "CA", 
      state == "Colorado" ~ "CO", 
      state == "Connecticut" ~ "CT", 
      state == "Delaware" ~ "DE", 
      state == "Florida" ~ "FL", 
      state == "Georgia" ~ "GA", 
      state == "Hawaii" ~ "HI", 
      state == "Idaho" ~ "ID", 
      state == "Illinois" ~ "IL", 
      state == "Indiana" ~ "IN", 
      state == "Iowa" ~ "IA", 
      state == "Kansas" ~ "KS", 
      state == "Kentucky" ~ "KY", 
      state == "Louisiana" ~ "LA", 
      state == "Maine" ~ "ME", 
      state == "Maryland" ~ "MD", 
      state == "Massachusetts" ~ "MA", 
      state == "Michigan" ~ "MI", 
      state == "Minnesota" ~ "MN", 
      state == "Mississippi" ~ "MS", 
      state == "Missouri" ~ "MO", 
      state == "Montana" ~ "MT", 
      state == "Nebraska" ~ "NE", 
      state == "Nevada" ~ "NV", 
      state == "New Hampshire" ~ "NH", 
      state == "New Jersey" ~ "NJ", 
      state == "New Mexico" ~ "NM", 
      state == "New York" ~ "NY", 
      state == "North Carolina" ~ "NC", 
      state == "North Dakota" ~ "ND", 
      state == "Ohio" ~ "OH", 
      state == "Oklahoma" ~ "OK", 
      state == "Oregon" ~ "OR", 
      state == "Pennsylvania" ~ "PA", 
      state == "Rhode Island" ~ "RI", 
      state == "South Carolina" ~ "SC", 
      state == "South Dakota" ~ "SD", 
      state == "Tennessee" ~ "TN", 
      state == "Texas" ~ "TX", 
      state == "Utah" ~ "UT", 
      state == "Vermont" ~ "VT", 
      state == "Virginia" ~ "VA", 
      state == "Washington" ~ "WA", 
      state == "West Virginia" ~ "WV", 
      state == "Wisconsin" ~ "WI", 
      state == "Wyoming" ~ "WY"
    ),
    seat_number = ifelse(
      state_abbr %in% c("WY", "VT", "SD", "ND", "DE", "CT"), 
      "00", 
      ifelse(
        state_abbr == "AK", 
        "99", 
        sprintf("%02d", seat_number)
      )
    ),
    district_id = trimws(paste(state_abbr, seat_number, sep = ""))
  ) |>
  filter(
    !is.na(state_abbr)
  )
```

```{r, results='hide'}
#| label: aggregate_house_polling_data

house_polling_aggregated <- house_polling |>
      mutate(
        pollscore = as.numeric(pollscore),
        sample_size = as.numeric(sample_size),
        numeric_grade = as.numeric(numeric_grade),
        start_date = as.Date(start_date, format="%m/%d/%y"),
        end_date = as.Date(end_date, format="%m/%d/%y")
    ) |>
    filter(
      party %in% c("DEM", "REP")
    ) |> 
    summarize(
        pct = round(weighted.mean(pct, sample_size, na.rm = TRUE),1),
        .by = c(state, party, state_abbr, district_id)
    ) |>
    pivot_wider(
      names_from = party,
      values_from = pct
    ) |>
    filter(
      !is.na(DEM),
      !is.na(REP)
    ) |>
    mutate(
      DEM_LEAD_PCT = DEM - REP
    )
```

```{r, results='hide'}
#| label: house_polling_and_spacial_data

house_polling_sf <- house_polling_aggregated |>
  inner_join(
    us_congressional_2022,
    join_by(district_id)
  )
```

```{r, results='hide', fig.width=10, fig.height=5}
#| label: house_polling_map

ggplot() +
    geom_sf(
        data = us_congressional_2022,
        aes(geometry = geometry),
        fill = "#E8E8E8",
        show.legend = FALSE
    ) +
    geom_sf(
        data = house_polling_sf,
        aes(geometry = geometry, fill=DEM_LEAD_PCT, color=DEM_LEAD_PCT),
        show.legend = TRUE
    ) +
    scale_fill_gradient2(high = "#002B84", mid = '#B9D7FF', low = "#800000", midpoint = 1.5) +
    scale_color_gradient2(high = "#00137F", mid = '#A1BBDD', low = "#630000", midpoint = 1.5) +
    labs(
      title="2026 United States House of Representatives Elections Polling",
      subtitle="(The data displayed on the map currently uses 2024 polling data instead of 2026 data for testing and outlining purposes)",
      caption="Source : FiveThirtyEight",
      fill="DEM-REP"
    ) +
    guides(color = "none") +
    theme_void() +
    theme(legend.position = "left")
```

## Senate Elections
33 of the 100 seats in the United States Senate will becontested. In additon to the 33 regularaly scheduled senatorial elections, there will be two special elections held in Ohio and Florida. Ohio due to J.D Vance vacating his seat when he is inaugurated as Vice President and Marco Rubio vacating his seat when he is (likely) nominated as Secretary of State.

